texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once upon a time, I spent hours and hours fumbling through openvpn configurations, certificates, and firewalls to get VPNs working between servers. One small configuration error led to lots of debugging. Adding new servers meant wallowing through this process all over again.
texts.text: Once upon a time, I spent hours and hours fumbling through openvpn configurations, certificates, and firewalls to get VPNs working between servers. One small configuration error led to lots of debugging. Adding new servers meant wallowing through this process all over again.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A friend told me about  Tailscale  and it makes private networking incredibly simple.
texts.text: A friend told me about  Tailscale  and it makes private networking incredibly simple.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Tailscale makes it easy to add nodes to a private network called a  tailnet  where they can communicate. In short, it's a dead simple mesh network (with advanced capabilities if you're interested).
texts.text: Tailscale makes it easy to add nodes to a private network called a  tailnet  where they can communicate. In short, it's a dead simple mesh network (with advanced capabilities if you're interested).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This post covers how to create an exit node for your Tailscale network using firewalld Fedora, CentOS Stream, and Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL).
texts.text: This post covers how to create an exit node for your Tailscale network using firewalld Fedora, CentOS Stream, and Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL).

texts.label: title
texts.orig: What's an exit node?
texts.text: What's an exit node?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Every node on a Tailscale network, or  tailnet , can communicate with each other[^acl]. However, it can use be useful to use one of those nodes on the network as an exit node.
texts.text: Every node on a Tailscale network, or  tailnet , can communicate with each other[^acl]. However, it can use be useful to use one of those nodes on the network as an exit node.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Exit nodes allow traffic to leave the tailnet and go out to other networks or the public internet. This allows you to join an untrusted network, such as a coffee shop's wifi network, and send your traffic out through one of your tailnet nodes. It works more like a traditional VPN.
texts.text: Exit nodes allow traffic to leave the tailnet and go out to other networks or the public internet. This allows you to join an untrusted network, such as a coffee shop's wifi network, and send your traffic out through one of your tailnet nodes. It works more like a traditional VPN.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Tailscale does this by changing the routes on your device to use the exit node on your tailnet for all traffic. Creating an exit node involves some configuration on the node itself and within Tailscale's administrative interface.
texts.text: Tailscale does this by changing the routes on your device to use the exit node on your tailnet for all traffic. Creating an exit node involves some configuration on the node itself and within Tailscale's administrative interface.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: [^acl]: Tailscale offers complex access control lists (ACLs) that allow you to limit connectivity based on tons of factors.
texts.text: [^acl]: Tailscale offers complex access control lists (ACLs) that allow you to limit connectivity based on tons of factors.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Deploy Tailscale
texts.text: Deploy Tailscale

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In this example, I'll use Fedora 36, but these instructions work for CentOS Stream and RHEL, too.
texts.text: In this example, I'll use Fedora 36, but these instructions work for CentOS Stream and RHEL, too.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Start by installing Tailscale on your system:
texts.text: Start by installing Tailscale on your system:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Fedora'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Fedora'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='CentOS Stream'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='CentOS Stream'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='RHEL'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='RHEL'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's get this going on Fedora:
texts.text: Let's get this going on Fedora:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ sudo dnf config-manager --add-repo https://pkgs.tailscale.com/stable/fedora/tailscale.repo
Adding repo from: https://pkgs.tailscale.com/stable/fedora/tailscale.repo
$ sudo dnf install tailscale
$ sudo systemctl enable --now tailscaled
$ sudo tailscale up

To authenticate, visit:

	https://login.tailscale.com/a/xxxxxx
texts.text:
$ sudo dnf config-manager --add-repo https://pkgs.tailscale.com/stable/fedora/tailscale.repo
Adding repo from: https://pkgs.tailscale.com/stable/fedora/tailscale.repo
$ sudo dnf install tailscale
$ sudo systemctl enable --now tailscaled
$ sudo tailscale up

To authenticate, visit:

	https://login.tailscale.com/a/xxxxxx

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Click the link to authorize the node to join your tailnet and it should appear in your list of nodes!
texts.text: Click the link to authorize the node to join your tailnet and it should appear in your list of nodes!

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Trusting the tailnet
texts.text: Trusting the tailnet

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In my case, I treat my tailnet interfaces as trusted interfaces on each node. (This might not fit your use case, so please read the docs on  Network access controls (ACLs)  if you need extra security layers.)
texts.text: In my case, I treat my tailnet interfaces as trusted interfaces on each node. (This might not fit your use case, so please read the docs on  Network access controls (ACLs)  if you need extra security layers.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Start by adding the new
texts.text: Start by adding the new

texts.label: code
texts.orig: tailscale0
texts.text: tailscale0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: interface as a trusted interface:
texts.text: interface as a trusted interface:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# firewall-cmd --add-interface=tailscale0 --zone=trusted
success
# firewall-cmd --list-all --zone=trusted
trusted (active)
  target: ACCEPT
  icmp-block-inversion: no
  interfaces: tailscale0
  sources: 
  services: 
  ports: 
  protocols: 
  forward: yes
  masquerade: no
  forward-ports: 
  source-ports: 
  icmp-blocks: 
  rich rules:
texts.text:
# firewall-cmd --add-interface=tailscale0 --zone=trusted
success
# firewall-cmd --list-all --zone=trusted
trusted (active)
  target: ACCEPT
  icmp-block-inversion: no
  interfaces: tailscale0
  sources: 
  services: 
  ports: 
  protocols: 
  forward: yes
  masquerade: no
  forward-ports: 
  source-ports: 
  icmp-blocks: 
  rich rules:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This permits all traffic in and out of the tailscale interface.
texts.text: This permits all traffic in and out of the tailscale interface.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Creating an exit node
texts.text: Creating an exit node

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's reconfigure tailscale to allow this node to serve as an exit node:
texts.text: Let's reconfigure tailscale to allow this node to serve as an exit node:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# tailscale up --advertise-exit-node
Warning: IP forwarding is disabled, subnet routing/exit nodes will not work.
See https://tailscale.com/kb/1104/enable-ip-forwarding/
texts.text:
# tailscale up --advertise-exit-node
Warning: IP forwarding is disabled, subnet routing/exit nodes will not work.
See https://tailscale.com/kb/1104/enable-ip-forwarding/

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Uh oh. Tailscale is telling us that it's happy to reconfigure itself, but we're going to run into IP forwarding issues. Let's see what our primary firewall zone has:
texts.text: Uh oh. Tailscale is telling us that it's happy to reconfigure itself, but we're going to run into IP forwarding issues. Let's see what our primary firewall zone has:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# firewall-cmd --list-all
public (active)
  target: default
  icmp-block-inversion: no
  interfaces: eth0
  sources: 
  services: dhcpv6-client mdns ssh
  ports: 
  protocols: 
  forward: yes
  masquerade: no
  forward-ports: 
  source-ports: 
  icmp-blocks: 
  rich rules:
texts.text:
# firewall-cmd --list-all
public (active)
  target: default
  icmp-block-inversion: no
  interfaces: eth0
  sources: 
  services: dhcpv6-client mdns ssh
  ports: 
  protocols: 
  forward: yes
  masquerade: no
  forward-ports: 
  source-ports: 
  icmp-blocks: 
  rich rules:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We can enable masquerading in firewalld and it will take care of everything for us, including NAT rules and
texts.text: We can enable masquerading in firewalld and it will take care of everything for us, including NAT rules and

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sysctl
texts.text: sysctl

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: settings for IP forwarding.
texts.text: settings for IP forwarding.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# firewall-cmd --add-masquerade --zone=public
success
# firewall-cmd --list-all | grep masq
  masquerade: yes
texts.text:
# firewall-cmd --add-masquerade --zone=public
success
# firewall-cmd --list-all | grep masq
  masquerade: yes

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's try the Tailscale reconfiguration once more:
texts.text: Let's try the Tailscale reconfiguration once more:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# tailscale up --advertise-exit-node
Warning: IPv6 forwarding is disabled.
Subnet routes and exit nodes may not work correctly.
See https://tailscale.com/kb/1104/enable-ip-forwarding/
texts.text:
# tailscale up --advertise-exit-node
Warning: IPv6 forwarding is disabled.
Subnet routes and exit nodes may not work correctly.
See https://tailscale.com/kb/1104/enable-ip-forwarding/

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We fixed the IPv4 forwarding, but IPv6 is still not configured properly. This was done automatically in the past, but firewalld  does not automatically enable IPv6 forwarding  in recent versions. Rich rules  come to the rescue:
texts.text: We fixed the IPv4 forwarding, but IPv6 is still not configured properly. This was done automatically in the past, but firewalld  does not automatically enable IPv6 forwarding  in recent versions. Rich rules  come to the rescue:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# firewall-cmd --add-rich-rule='rule family=ipv6 masquerade'
success
# sysctl -a | grep net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding
net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding = 1
texts.text:
# firewall-cmd --add-rich-rule='rule family=ipv6 masquerade'
success
# sysctl -a | grep net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding
net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding = 1

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One more try:
texts.text: One more try:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: # tailscale up --advertise-exit-node
texts.text: # tailscale up --advertise-exit-node

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Success! But wait, we still can't send traffic through the exit node until we authorize it in the Tailscale admin interface:
texts.text: Success! But wait, we still can't send traffic through the exit node until we authorize it in the Tailscale admin interface:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go back to your
texts.text: Go back to your

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Right underneath the name of the node, you should see
texts.text: Right underneath the name of the node, you should see

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click the three dots on the far right of that row and click
texts.text: Click the three dots on the far right of that row and click

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When the modal appears, click the slider to the left of
texts.text: When the modal appears, click the slider to the left of

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now you can test your exit node from your mobile device by choosing an exit node via the settings menu. Another Linux machine can use it as an exit node as well just by running another
texts.text: Now you can test your exit node from your mobile device by choosing an exit node via the settings menu. Another Linux machine can use it as an exit node as well just by running another

texts.label: code
texts.orig: tailscale up
texts.text: tailscale up

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: command:
texts.text: command:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Start using an exit node.
sudo tailscale up --exit-node my-exit-node-name

# Stop using an exit node.
sudo tailscale up --exit-node ''
texts.text:
# Start using an exit node.
sudo tailscale up --exit-node my-exit-node-name

# Stop using an exit node.
sudo tailscale up --exit-node ''
